<p>Jacob and his dad have no idea how to play <em>Kerbal Space Program</em>, but that’s ok. People of all ages can enjoy this family friendly let’s play series and learn with the hosts. Have a look at <a href="http://bit.ly/1qAdh03"><strong>Kinder Playtime</strong></a>.</p>
That was a cool little video, thanks for sharing.
I enjoyed it. Maybe if he gave the controls to the kid so we could see what would happen.

The potential of KSP as an educational family game is highly under-rated. My four-year-old daughter and I play together frequently, and she's fallen in love with the Kerbals. It's a great opportunity to explore both basic physics principles (gravity, drag, etc.) and even more advanced concepts (orbits, Karman line, apoapsis, transfers, etc.) in a very accessible and qualitative manner.

We've tried that a couple of times; it usually ends up on some form of command capsule plus oversized rocket engine--no fuel, no seperators, etc. This will usually be capped off by a full spread of eight launch supporters. Sometimes we'll get lucky and she'll remember a booster or two, but even that is never balanced and so the results are spectacular. I can't bring myself to "correct" her, as it's so much fun.

Don't want to be the buzzkill here, but I think they need to learn that's no Earth, and that they have MMU's so they can get back to the ship, and learn about different types of fuel, and electricity, and basic orbital mechanics. You can't just go up and you'll be in space forever.

As much as I want them to learn, they must learn the cold and hard truth. Though I think they are too young for KSP anyway, the least you can do is correct them if they think going straight up will get you to space. You should tell them that if you just go up, you will fall down and make them think of a way of staying up in space by themselves instead of giving them already prepared information on a nice and clean plate.

You don't teach kids knew stuff, you give them bits of info and they put it together to form their own ideas. That is how kids should be taught.

To learn to learn, not to just learn new stuff.
